article_title: Behind the Chronic Weakness of Capital Investment
article_text:
Corporate profits and cash flow are strong, cash on the books of American firms is at record highs, and prospects for future economic growth are promising. Yet capital investment, which is one of the main pillars of growing productivity and rising living standards, is historically weak. Understanding why is crucial to reversing course and fostering a more robust economy.

In 2014, real gross domestic product was 8.7% above the level it reached just before the onset of the great recession in late 2007, according to the...

twitter.description: Thomas J. Duesterberg and Donald A. Norman writing about the chronic weakness of capital investment, say that companies have lots of cash on the books but are slow to lay it out—one reason why productivity has slowed.
twitter.title: Behind the Chronic Weakness of Capital Investment
